misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from three input values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers and summing only the even ones. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the stated problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles and computes the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check which are even using n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Program reads 3 values instead of 5.
Program uses double variables and a physics formula rather than summing even integers.
No loop, no conditional even check, and no accumulator for the sum of even numbers appear in the code.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code from a different problem (average acceleration) or did not carefully read and translate the specific requirements of this question into an algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and restate it in your own words. Design the algorithm step by step: (1) read 5 integers, (2) for each one, check if it is even with n % 2 == 0, (3) if it is even, add it to a running sum, and (4) print the final sum. Only then start coding that algorithm.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and variable naming clearly correspond to an average-acceleration physics problem, with no elements related to reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Code reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, showing the problem requirements were misinterpreted.

misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem (Average Acceleration)
misconceptions.description: The student's submission calculates the average acceleration using the formula A = (V1 - V0) / T instead of implementing the program required by Q1: finding the sum of five input even integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task was to calculate average acceleration based on initial velocity (V0), final velocity (V1), and time (T).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 numbers, identifying which ones are even, and calculating their sum.
symptoms: Incorrect prompt text ('Enter v0, v1, and t:')
Reads only three double values instead of five integers
Performs a calculation that is irrelevant to the prompt (acceleration formula)
Missing loop structure
Missing conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the assignment question or confusing the required problem with sample code from a different lesson/homework problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the assignment requirement: 'Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.' Focus on implementing a structure that handles 5 inputs iteratively and uses the modulo operator (%) to check for evenness.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly implements a textbook formula for average acceleration, with corresponding variable names and prompts, indicating a complete mismatch with the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: The input prompt asks for variables (v0, v1, t) related to kinematics, not 5 general integers.
Reads three double values instead of five integers.
Calculation is for acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.
Output states 'average acceleration', confirming the error.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have solved a completely different problem. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers, the student wrote code that reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and calculates acceleration.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they should read 3 variables and calculate acceleration using the formula (V1 - V0) / T.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking which ones are even (using n % 2 == 0), and summing only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Code performs acceleration calculation instead of even number sum
Output message is about acceleration, not sum of even numbers
No loop structure present to process 5 inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either read the wrong problem statement, misunderstood the assignment requirements, or submitted code for a different problem entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully. The task is to: (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop through them, (3) check if each is even using (n % 2 == 0), (4) sum only the even ones, and (5) print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is fundamentally solving a different problem with different inputs, different calculations, and different output. This is unambiguously a misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: The code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration, completely different from the requirement to read 5 integers and sum even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Solved an entirely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones. This indicates a misunderstanding or disregard of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read initial velocity, final velocity, and time, then compute and print the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integer values from the user, determine which of them are even using a condition like n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of only those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompts the user for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
Reads three double values rather than five integers.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0).
Computes (V1 - V0) / T and prints "The average acceleration is" instead of summing even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the assignment instructions, likely copying or reusing code from a different physics-related problem instead of implementing the requested sum-of-evens task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design a fresh solution: plan to read 5 integers (e.g., with a loop), use an if-condition to check if each number is even (n % 2 == 0), keep a running total of even numbers, and finally print the sum of those even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code is focused on average acceleration and there is no sign of any logic related to reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The code clearly solves an average-acceleration problem with three double inputs instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (A = (V1 - V0) / T), which is entirely unrelated to the requested task of reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of the even numbers among them. The student failed to address the core problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment requires calculating acceleration based on input velocities and time, or they submitted code for the wrong assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires repeated input reading (5 times), conditional logic (checking for evenness using modulo), and accumulation of a sum.
symptoms: Code solves a completely different physics problem (acceleration calculation)
Input prompts ask for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'
Variables used (V0, V1, T, A) do not relate to summing integers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either copied code from a different assignment or completely misunderstood the required task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem description: 'Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.' Focus on implementing a loop structure and the modulo operator for condition checking.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code is structurally sound but addresses a different problem (acceleration calculation), making the misinterpretation undeniable.

evidence.note: The entire logic and output are related to acceleration calculation, not summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Number and Type of Inputs Read
misconceptions.description: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, but the student only reads 3 double-precision floating-point numbers (V0, V1, T). This indicates a lack of understanding regarding how to correctly implement repeated input reading tailored to the required data types.
misconceptions.student_belief: Inputs consist of 3 distinct velocities/time measurements, and doubles are the appropriate data type.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use INPUT.nextInt() and read 5 separate values, typically using a loop construct.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
Only reads 3 variables instead of 5 iterations
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of problem parameters leading to procedural error in input handling.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure you are using the correct Scanner method (e.g., nextInt()) for the required data type (integers) and structure your code to handle the required quantity (5 inputs), likely using a loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Code explicitly uses nextDouble() three times, violating the requirement for 5 integer inputs.

evidence.note: Only three inputs are read, and they are doubles, not 5 integers as required.

misconceptions.task: Reading 5 integers from input; Loop structure to process inputs; Conditional check for even numbers; Accumulating sum and printing result
misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: Student has apparently misunderstood the assignment entirely and implemented a solution to a different problem (calculating average acceleration). This represents a fundamental failure to read and understand the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The assignment asks to calculate average acceleration given three values (initial velocity, final velocity, and time).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment asks to read exactly 5 integers from the user and compute the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Program prompts for 3 different variables (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Program reads floating-point numbers instead of integers
Program performs arithmetic (V1-V0)/T instead of checking for even numbers
Program outputs acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure implemented
No even/odd checking logic present
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read the assignment requirements. They may have confused this problem with a different exercise or worked on the wrong question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the problem statement carefully. The goal is to: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) Loop through them, (3) Check if each is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) Sum the even ones, (5) Print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) with no overlap to the assignment requirements (sum of even numbers). The variable names (v0, v1, t), data types (double), and computation (subtraction/division) all point to a physics problem, not a number-filtering problem.

evidence.note: Student is reading 3 physics variables and computing acceleration, not reading 5 integers and computing sum of evens
Output is about acceleration, not sum of even numbers
